title: 111_hr3133
content: The Act may be cited as the "Foreign Evidence Request Efficiency Act of 2009" and includes improvements to Title 18. Title 18 of the United States Code is amended to specify procedures for court-issued warrants in different subsections. Title 18 of the United States Code is amended to specify procedures for court-issued warrants in different subsections, including the definition of a court of competent jurisdiction and the inclusion of any district court of the United States. Title 18 of the United States Code is amended to specify procedures for court-issued warrants, including the definition of a court of competent jurisdiction as any district court of the United States with specific criteria for jurisdiction. The amendment to Title 18 of the United States Code specifies procedures for court-issued warrants, defining a court of competent jurisdiction as any district court of the United States meeting specific criteria. The amendment to Title 18 of the United States Code specifies procedures for court-issued warrants, defining a court of competent jurisdiction as any district court of the United States meeting specific criteria, including jurisdiction over the offense being investigated, location of the provider of a wire or electronic communication service, location of a landlord, custodian, or other person subject to certain sections, or acting on a request for foreign assistance. The amendment to Title 18 of the United States Code outlines procedures for court-issued warrants, specifying that a Federal judge may issue orders to execute foreign requests for assistance in criminal investigations and prosecutions. Upon application by an authorized Department of Justice official or government attorney, a Federal judge can issue orders to assist foreign authorities in criminal investigations or prosecutions, including search warrants and requests for electronic communication records. Upon application, a Federal judge may issue various orders to assist in criminal investigations, including search warrants, warrants for electronic communication records, orders for pen registers or trap and trace devices, and orders for testimony, statements, or document production. A Federal judge may issue orders for the production of documents, testimony, or statements in response to a request from a foreign authority. Additionally, the judge can appoint a person to oversee the collection of evidence and issue orders for appearance or document production. A Federal judge may appoint a person to oversee the collection of evidence and issue orders for appearance or document production in response to a request from a foreign authority. The appointed person has the authority to issue orders, administer oaths, take testimony, and receive documents. Requests for execution of a foreign authority's request can be filed in the district where the person resides or where the documents are located. An application for execution of a request from a foreign authority under this section may be filed in the district where the person resides, where the documents are located, where a related Federal criminal investigation is being conducted, or in the District of Columbia. An application for a search warrant from a foreign authority under this section must be filed in the district where the place or person to be searched is located. A Federal judge can issue a search warrant only if the foreign offense involves conduct punishable by imprisonment for more than one year in the US. An application for a search warrant from a foreign authority under this section must be filed in the district where the place or person to be searched is located. The warrant can only be issued if the foreign offense involves conduct punishable by imprisonment for more than one year in the US. The order or warrant issued can be served in any place in the United States, and foreign authorities or interested persons can seek assistance in criminal investigations or prosecutions under section 1782 of title 28, United States Code. The definitions for "Federal judge" and "Foreign authority" are provided in this section, relating to obtaining assistance in criminal investigations or prosecutions under section 1782 of title 28, United States Code. The curr_chunk adds a new definition for "Foreign authority" in relation to criminal investigations or prosecutions under section 1782 of title 28, United States Code. The curr_chunk introduces a new definition for "Foreign authority" in relation to criminal investigations or prosecutions under section 1782 of title 28, United States Code.
